review.title: Information Density as a Factor for Variation in the Embedding of Relative Clauses
review.abstract: In German, relative clauses can be positioned in-situ or extraposed. A potential factor for the variation might be information density. In this study, this hypothesis is tested with a corpus of 17th century German funeral sermons. For each referent in the relative clauses and their matrix clauses, the attention state was determined (first calculation). In a second calculation, for each word the surprisal values were determined, using a bi-gram language model. In a third calculation, the surprisal values were accommodated as to whether it is the first occurrence of the word in question or not. All three calculations pointed in the same direction: With in-situ relative clauses, the rate of new referents was lower and the average surprisal values were lower, especially the accommodated surprisal values, than with extraposed relative clauses. This indicated that in-formation density is a factor governing the choice between in-situ and extraposed relative clauses. The study also sheds light on the intrinsic relation-ship between the information theoretic concept of information density and in-formation structural concepts such as givenness which are used under a more linguistic perspective.

sections.text: In this study, this hypothesis is tested with a corpus of 17th-century German sermons on the dead. Attention levels were determined for each speaker in the relative sentences and their matrix clauses (first calculation); in a second calculation, surprise scores were determined for each word using a two-gram language model; in a third calculation, surprise scores were taken into account in terms of whether the word was the first occurrence or not; all three calculations pointed in the same direction: in-situ relative clauses had a lower rate of new speakers and average surprise scores were lower, especially the adjusted surprise scores, than extrapolated relative clauses, indicating that information density is a factor determining the choice between in-situ and extrapolated relative clauses; and the study also sheds light on the intrinsic relationship between the information-theoretical concept of information density and the information structures used:

Note that the matrix clauses of in situ relative clauses also have a low ratio of new speakers, compared to the matrix clauses of extrapolated relative clauses. We could interpret this as meaning that sentence complexes that do not contain many new speakers, neither in the relative clauses nor in the matrix clauses, allow freer bundling variants.

sections.heading: 3.2 Second Calculation (Bare Surprisal Values)
sections.text: The results of the second calculation are in Table 2. Here, the surprise values of all articles (= lemmata), calculated using a branch gram language model, are added (adS) and the mean (avS). This was done separately for all clauses (relative clauses and matrix clauses), in the case of the in situ relative clauses, also the adS and avS of the combined clause were calculated. Note that this is not simply the sum of the values of the in situ relative clause and its matrix clause. For the surprise values of the clauses themselves, in situ relative clauses were calculated as if they were extrapolated. As the surprise values are calculated via bigrams, the context of some words would change whether the relative clause is in situ or not, the most noteworthy is the surprise value of the word immediately after the in situ relative clause.

sections.heading: 3.3 Third Calculation (Surprisal with Accomodation)
sections.text: The results of the third calculation are in Table 3. Here, the surprise value of each word in terms of content was multiplied by a factor determined using the algorithm described in Section 2. AdS and avS were then calculated as in the second calculation. Similar effects are evident from the mere surprise values of the second calculation, since there is a striking difference between the values of the extrapolated and the in-situ relative clauses. The AvS of the extrapolated variants is about 18.4, much more than the avS of the in-situ variants (13.9), which is 76% of the extrapolated value. However, one difference is that the adjusted surprise values of the matrix clauses also play a role: the AvD of the matrix clauses on in-situ relative clauses is almost identical to the avD of their relative clauses.
